passages.text: EQUITY: AGRI- RELATED
Fig. 1: Nomura CPO price gauge  We expect CPO prices to remain at \(\sim\) MYR4,375/MT until 4 September
Source: Nomura estimates

CPO (crude palm oil) spot prices declined \(1\%\) w- w to MYR4,370/MT in the week ended 28 August 2025, according to the Malaysia Palm Oil Board (MPOB). This was largely due to lower prices of soybean oil due to concerns over demand in the US. For the next week, we expect prices to remain stable as rising exports are balanced by weaker soybean oil prices. Overall, we expect the average CPO price to remain at MYR4,375/MT until 4 September. However, if exports from Malaysia rise sharply or if production concerns rise, CPO prices could increase to MYR4,450/MT.

US EPA approves biofuel waivers for small refiners, stirring concerns over demand According to a 23 August article in Reuters (link), the US EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) has approved most of its backlog of waivers by small oil refiners, leading to concerns over biofuel demand. Under the Renewable Fuel Standard, US refiners must either blend biofuels such as ethanol into the nation's fuel supply or buy RINS (renewable identification numbers) generated by those that blend biofuels. The small refiners are now exempt from the financial mandate as they were able to prove that the obligation would cause them financial hardship.

OurView: The exemption for small refiners is likely to impact the demand for biofuels and their feedstock, including corn and soybean, leading to lower prices. However, if the EPA balances these exemptions with higher obligations for larger refiners, it could mitigate this impact, in our view.

Following two months of weak exports, we are seeing signs of improvement in August. According to Intertek, total palm oil exports rose \(11\%\) m- m during 1- 25 August. This is largely because of exports to Europe rising \(59\%\) m- m, to India rising \(24\%\) m- m, to China rising \(16\%\) m- m, and to the Middle East rising \(33\%\) m- m. In contrast, exports to Africa declined \(10\%\) m- m, to the Americas declined \(70\%\) , and to Asia Oceania declined \(5\%\) m- m.
Our view: For August, we continue to expect exports to rise \(\sim 10\%\) m- m due to higher exports to India and Europe.
See Appendix A- 1 for analyst certification, important disclosures and the status of non- US analysts.

According to a 26 August article in Reuters (link), Malaysia's commodities ministry is seeking to exempt crude palm kernel oil (CPKO) and palm kernel olein oil from the recently announced \(5\%\) sales and service tax (SST). According to the ministry, the exemption is justified as both are raw materials used in the production of oleochemical products and are not the final products.

Our view: We agree with the ministry's view that CPKO and palm kernel olein oil should be exempt from the SST as they are raw materials. Prices for these products have increased sharply over the past year due to lower supply and higher demand for coconut oil, a key rival for the production of lauric products. If these raw materials are exempt from SST, it would be positive for the margins of oleochemical companies.

According to a 25 August article in Reuters (link), Indonesia has asked the EU to scrap countervailing duties on the imports of biodiesel after the World Trade Organization (WTO) held that Indonesia's export duty and export levy on palm oil could not be categorized as a subsidy. Following the imposition of duties ranging from \(8\%\) to \(18\%\) by the EU in 2019, Indonesia's export of palm oil- based biodiesel declined from \(1.32\mathrm{mn}\) kl in 2019 to 27,000kl in 2024.

Our view: The EU's imposition of countervailing duties came a year after the European Court of Justice ordered them to remove anti- dumping duties on Indonesian biodiesel and given this track record, we do not expect the EU to revoke these curbs. However, if these curbs were to be reduced, it would lead to an increase in the demand for CPO from the biodiesel industry and be positive for the prices of CPO, while it could be negative for the prices of rapeseed oil.

Indonesia says US agreed to tariff exemption for its palm oil, cocoa and rubber According to a 26 August article in Reuters (link), the US has agreed in principle to exempt Indonesian exports of palm oil, cocoa and rubber from the \(19\%\) tariff imposed since 7 August. The exemption is expected to take effect once the final agreement has been reached. According to the article, the countries have also discussed potential US investment in fuel storage in Indonesia in partnership with Danantara and state energy firm Pertamina.

Our view: We understand that currently \(- 8\%\) of Indonesia's palm oil exports go to the US, compared with \(- 2\%\) to Malaysia. If the \(19\%\) tariff is reduced or removed, we believe it would be beneficial for Indonesian exports to the US and could lead to loss of share for Malaysian companies. However, we believe Malaysia could also secure a similar tariff waiver or reduction from the US.

According to a 26 August article in Reuters (link), a Brazilian judge has suspended a decision from an antitrust Watchdog CADE (Administrative Council for Economic Defense) that had ordered grating traders to halt their "soy moratorium" program. This private pact had been created to protect the Amazon rainforest by barring soybean traders from sourcing soybean from farmers who cleared land post- 2008. CADE had given traders 10 days to suspend the moratorium or face fines. The judge has now suspended the decision until a full CADE panel makes its final decision.

Our view: While we see the judge's suspension of the earlier CADE decision as a positive for sustainability in the industry, we note that it will likely lead to slightly higher prices for Brazilian soybean, especially given the strong demand from China. Higher prices of soybean will be a positive for CPO prices.

Valuation Methodology We derive our target price of MYR4.50 based on 18.5x FY26F PER, which is one standard deviation below its long term average. The benchmark index for this stock is the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index. Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Key downside risks: (1) Lower than expected CPO prices; (2) Higher than expected cost of production due to rising wages, fertilizer costs; (3) Continued shortage of foreign labor for Malaysia operations
Source: LSEG, Nomura

Valuation Methodology We derive our target price of MYR23.0 based on 17x average of FY26F PER, which is one standard deviation below its long term average. The benchmark index for this stock is the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index. Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Key downside risks: (1) Lower than expected CPO prices; (2) Higher than expected cost of production due to rising wages, fertilizer costs; (3) Continued shortage of foreign labor for Malaysia operations; and (4) Delay in getting RSPO certification for erstwhile IJM Plantations land.
For explanation of ratings refer to the stock rating keys located after chart(s)
Valuation Methodology We derive our target price of MYR5.80 based on 17x FY25F P/E. The benchmark index for this stock is the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Key downside risks: 1) lower than expected CPO prices; 2) higher than expected cost of production due to rising wages, fertilizer costs; and 3) shortage of foreign labor for Malaysia operations.
For explanation of ratings refer to the stock rating keys located after chart(s)

Valuation Methodology Our TP of IDR2,100 is derived from 2025F P/E of 13x, slightly higher than regional peers at 12x FY25E P/E (consensus). The benchmark using JCI Index Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price A downside risk would be higher-than- expected fertilizer costs.
For explanation of ratings refer to the stock rating keys located after chart(s)

Valuation Methodology Our target price of SGD3.20 is based on a sum- of- the- parts valuation. We value Wilmar's food products at 20x FY25F P/E, feed and industrial products at 10x and plantations and sugar milling business at 14x FY25F P/E. We also apply a \(20\%\) conglomerate discount.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Key upside risk: 1) Strong recovery in agricultural commodity prices including soybean and palm oil in FY25F; 2) Favorable conclusion of Guangzhou Yihai indictment in China; and 3) Stronger than expected crush margins in China. Key downside risks: 1) Further weakness in the Chinese economy in FY25F; 2) weaker economic environment in India; and 3) further decline in prices of food, feed and industrial products in FY25F.

A rating of 'Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Neutral', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to perform in line with the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Reduce', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Suspended', indicates that the rating, target price and estimates have been suspended temporarily to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies. Securities and/or companies that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'No rating' are not in regular research coverage. Investors should not expect continuing or additional information from Nomura relating to such securities and/or companies. Benchmarks are as follows: United States/Europe/Asia ex- Japan: please see valuation methodologies for explanations of relevant benchmarks for stocks, which can be accessed at: http://go.nomuranow.com/research/m/Disclosures; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia, unless otherwise stated in the valuation methodology; Japan: Russell/Nomura Large Cap.

A 'Bullish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to outperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Neutral' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to perform in line with the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A 'Bearish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to underperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. Sectors that are labelled as 'Not rated' or shown as 'N/A' are not assigned ratings. Benchmarks are as follows: United States: S&P 500; Europe: Dow Jones STOXX 600; Global Emerging Markets (ex- Asia): MSCI Emerging Markets ex- Asia. Japan/Asia ex- Japan: Sector ratings are not assigned.

A Target Price, if discussed, indicates the analyst's forecast for the share price with a 12- month time horizon, reflecting in part the analyst's estimates for the company's earnings. The achievement of any target price may be impeded by general market and macroeconomic trends, and by other risks related to the company or the market, and may not occur if the company's earnings differ from estimates.
